ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about international modes of governance and the institutions which are responsible for cooperation among nations.
How the world powers approach global issues, what the current issues are in Global Governance

I learned a lot about the structure and function of global governance organizations like the UN and major challenges facing the world (maintaining human rights, public health, facing climate change, dealing with the rise of technology, etc).
A lot of flexibility to choose research paper topics, got to learn a lot and was given great resources about things I was personally interested in learning about

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
I think the course balanced depth and breadth very well as the lectures both built off of one another, but also covered new material regularly.

I think the course could have implemented more casual roundtable discussion among students rather than just formal presentations.
The course is a seminar, but is taught like a lecture. Student engagement is encouraged, but students oftentimes don't understand how exactly to engage.

This course was interesting and the workload was manageable. We got to write our papers on topics of our choosing -- so this was super engaging and interesting.
It was really more a lecture than a seminar, which was fine because Professor Sergeyev has so many amazing life experiences that directly apply to the course.
The class is a good overview of concepts in global governance. At times the slides can be confusing and wordy, it is best to just listen to lecture rather than reading the content after the fact.

One strength of this course was how open-ended the papers were, which made it really easy to find a topic you were personally interested in. One weakness was that at times the class was poorly organized and not really conducive to discussions.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I think this course provides students with a lot of freedom to hone in on a specific aspect of global affairs and direct deep research in the direction of their choosing.
Yes. The professor is very knowledgeable about Global Governance and provides astounding feedback.
Yes, if you are interested in global governance and how countries should approach global issues! I learned a lot.

I would recommend this course to a student that is able to remain involved and engaged in seminar style discussion. This class is only as enjoyable as the students make it. If you ask questions and speak, you will do well and the 2 and a half hour meetings will go by shortly. But, if you are not engaged the lectures can last forever. Likewise, the grading schemes and due dates for the papers are not well articulated by Prof. Sergeyev. It is best to remain in contact with him and ask questions if you want to understand the assignments.
Yes, especially if you're interested in the UN, international law, and the main challenges facing the world
Yes! Prof is extremely knowledgeable, no busy work, learned a lot from presentations and research papers assigned.
